bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, May 17, 1948

div1.p: Lyons informs Hench that she has tried to recognize Finlay as fully as possible in the Hall of Fame event, but insists that the event honors Reed, not Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, May 17, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME : NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N.Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
17 May 1948
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of the 15th of May, which
we received this morning. I think the way you handled the
Finlay matter in Washington was very diplomatic, and I hope
that the newspapers here will give a proper slant to their
story. Of course you know that we issue the releases from our
Publicity Department of the University, and frankly, so far
as we are concerned at the moment, (and I say this without
deprecating Finlay's part in the extermination of yellow fever)
Reed is really the person we are honoring. As you know, I have
tried to give Finlay as much credit as possible in the makeup
of our own program of the event, and I purposely chose letters
of Walter Reed in which he mentioned, not only Finlay, but
Carroll and Lazear. As a matter of fact, Finlay is mentioned
three times in the program: first, in the explanatory addenda
accompanying the painting by Dean Cornwell; second, his photo-
graph along with those of Lazear, Carroll and Agramonte and
third, in the letter of December 9 in which Reed gives Finlay
credit for the mosquito theory. I think, in a program honoring
Walter Reed, this is more than generous to Finlay. In the final
analysis, as you and I know, it was as Dr. Joseph Goldberger
said, Reed who “converted a discredited theory into an established
doctrine.” The Reed experiments are in many respects like the
anaesthesia problems. Of course Wells and Long and the others
all made their experiments with anaesthesia, but actually, until
Morton performed the operation at the Massachusetts General
Hospital, humanity was not benefited. Personally, I feel the
same way about Reed and yellow fever. Finlay had his theory of
the mosquito, but until Reed and the other members of the
Commission were set to work nothing was done about it.

I know how important it is to be diplomatic with the
Cubans in this matter, and I shall, as you suggest, call
Dr. Nogueira on the telephone and confirm the invitation which
was sent to him some time ago. His name was given to us a long
time ago by the American Foundation for Tropical Medicine, and
Dr. Philip S. Hench
2.
May 17, 1948
the invitation was sent to him but we have had neither a regret
nor an acceptance, which I think is being a little over temper-
mental. Of course, there is the possibility that the invitation
arrived in Cuba when he had already left for the Congresses in
Washington.

In view of what you say about this whole thing and the
controversy in general, I shall tell Dr. Angell of the situation,
and I am sure that he will handle it diplomatically, though in all
fairness to you, I think I must tell you that I do not feel that
Dr. Angell will be inclined at our ceremony to give credit to
Dr. Finlay to any measurable extent, when the ceremony is in
honor of Walter Reed. However, I shall put the matter to
him as diplomatically as I know how.

You probably have not had a chance to see any of the
Sunday New York papers (May 16). The New York Times and the New
York Tribune both carried good stories of the Reed ceremony on
the 20th and gave biographical facts. This was our first story
which we issued in connection with the event. There will be
another story that will be released by the University for
Thursday morning. However, this story will carry few, if any,
biographical facts. It will merely be a story of the event,
featuring the actual exercises, and more particularly, the
speakers and those who will attend.

You may be interested to know that in the address of
General Bliss no mention has been made of Dr. Finlay, but
Dr. Sawyer will say this when he reads his paper on Reed:

“We are here to honor Walter Reed and voice the
gratitude of a nation to the man who freed it from the
ever-recurring terror of yellow fever. It was he who
conceived and directed the masterful experiments in
Cuba which showed how the disease was spread and the
way in which it could be prevented. These experiments
were so simple that the man on the street could under-
stand them and so conclusive that the scientist accepted
the results as proof. No longer could the health
authorities hesitate to accept the mosquito theory of
Carlos Finlay, now so convincingly proved. With this
new knowledge the public could be given complete
protection against this terrible pestilence, and many
futile and burdensome measures could be abandoned.
To few has it been given to render so important a
service in so short a time and with such immediate
and vast benefit to mankind.”
Farther along in his address, Dr. Sawyer says:

“There were several recent developments in medical
science that suggested the possibility of insect trans-
mission in yellow fever. It soon became apparent to
Reed that it ought to be settled once and for all
whether the disease was spread by a mosquito, as had
been maintained for nineteen years by Carlos Finlay . . .
Dr. Finlay supplied eggs of the suspected culex fasciatus
mosquito and told Dr. Lazear how to care for the
insects.”

Incidentally, I think Dr. Sawyer's paper is an admirable one
giving credit not only to Finlay but to all of Reed's colleagues.
I think you will like it very much.

I have not yet received Dr. Salisbury's paper and so
I do not know what he is saying in his presentation remarks.
I doubt very much whether he will cover the biographical angle.

I wired you this morning advising you that the car with
the Reed family will stop for you at the Waldorf Astoria at two
o'clock d.s.t. on Thursday, the 20th.

I hope you as a physician do not think me presumptuous
in offering my opinion regarding Finlay in this matter. Frankly,
as a lay person I am very ignorant of the whole matter from a
medical aspect. I am merely viewing it in the light of history
and what history has now established, namely, that it was
Reed's persistence and hard work and all of the experiments which
he performed, which made it possible to eliminate the scourge of
yellow fever.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director BLL:yz
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
P. S. I do not know how familiar you are with the New York press,
but it is not easy to tell our newspapers what to say and
what not to say. They are men of very determined opinions
of their own, but if you feel that you would like to talk
to the members of the press after the ceremony issuing a
statement in your own name, we certainly have no objection
to your doing so.
P.P.S. I have just received and read AV. Salisbury's address-
he pays a magnificent trebute to Finlay & the others,
B.L.L.
